definitions.definition: two things of the same type, especially when they are used or worn together

examples.text: a **pair of shoes/boots**
a pair of gloves/earrings
She pulled on the pair of socks he handed her.
a huge pair of eyes
A pair of hands grasped her shoulders.
a pair of aces/kings *(= two playing cards that have the same value)*
The winner will receive a pair of tickets to Reykjavik.
The vase is one of a **matching pair**.
Vermeer painted the two pictures as a pair.
This sculpture was originally one of a pair owned by the King of France.
a clean pair of socks

definitions.definition: an object consisting of two parts that are joined together

examples.text: a **pair of trousers/pants/jeans**
a **pair of glasses/binoculars/scissors**
Buy one pair of glasses and get a second pair free.
He was wearing a nice pair of denim jeans.

definitions.definition: two people who are doing something together or who have a particular relationship

examples.text: Get pairs of students to act out the dialogue in front of the class.
Get the students to do the exercise as **pair work** *(= two students work together)*.
I've had enough of the pair of you!
They might seem an unlikely pair, but they've been friends for years.
I thought they would make a good pair so I arranged for them to meet.
The pair were matched for age.
They make an odd pair.

definitions.definition: two animals or birds of the same type that are producing young together

examples.text: a breeding pair
a pair of swans
**pair bonding** *(= the process of animals forming a pair for breeding)*
The dominant pair is/are called the alpha male and female.

definitions.definition: two horses working together to pull a carriage

examples.text: a carriage and pair

definitions.definition: in groups of two objects or people

examples.text: Students worked in pairs on the project.
These candles only come in pairs.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are too busy to do anything else
a person who can do, or is doing, a job

examples.text: We need an extra pair of hands if we're going to finish on time.

definitions.definition: a person that you can trust to do a job well

examples.text: Colleagues regard him as a safe pair of hands.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French paire, from Latin paria ‘equal things’, neuter plural of par ‘equal’. Formerly phrases such as a pair of gloves were expressed without of, as in a pair gloves (compare with German ein Paar Handschuhe).
